Award.AwardTitle: Fundamental Study of Wear in Graphene Nanocomposites

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this grant is to elucidate the fundamental mechanisms that are responsible for the suppression of wear in graphene-polymer composites. Our goal in this project is to develop an in-depth understanding of the enhanced ability of graphene additives to resist wear in polymers. Graphene is interesting from the point of view of wear suppression since it has in-plane sheet dimensions of the order of several microns coupled with nanometer scale sheet thickness. The microscale dimensions of the graphene sheets enables it to effectively interfere with debris generation processes in polymers, while the nanometer scale thickness, low density and planer sheet geometry of graphene enables a huge interfacial contact area with very large number density of graphene platelets in the matrix. Moreover, the sliding of individual graphene planes within graphene platelets is expected to enhance the lubrication effect and reduce the friction levels in addition to the material wear rates.

If successful, the proposed work will provide the fundamental understanding necessary to enable the rational design of wear-resistant graphene polymer composites. The excellent wear suppression ability of graphene fillers coupled with their potentially low production cost makes this technology very promising for industrial applications. Such composites offering reduced friction and wear have a wide range of applications in the aerospace, medical, chemical, automotive and electronics industries. Outreach activities include demonstrations to students from New York State's New Visions high school program. This will help to popularize science and to attract underrepresented groups to careers in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has helped to develop a fundamental understanding of the mechanisms that control wear in graphene-polymer composites. The project was focused on the polmer (teflon) which is widely used by industry as a solid lubricant. We filled teflon with graphene (which is a single atom thick, two-dimensional sheet of carbon atoms) and studied its wear and friction properties.

We showed up to 4-orders of magnitude reduction in the wear rate of Teflon by use of graphene additives. The main mechanism for this was shown to be the ability of graphene platelets to deflect sub-surface cracks in the material thereby regulating the wear debris size. Another important mechanism was shown to be the ability of graphene to affect the crystallinity and microstructure of teflon by stabilizing the tougher phase-I of teflon. We optimized the geometry of the graphene fillers and showed that thinner graphene platelets work the best. We also showed that increasing the loading fraction of graphene in the composite has a beneficial effect on the wear suppression. Finally, we showed that the friction of graphene-teflon composites is also reduced when compared to the pristine (unfilled) teflon.

The above results indicate that graphene additives have remarkable potential to improve the tribological (friction and wear) performance of solid lubricants such as teflon. The results from this NSF funded project provide the fundamental understanding necessary to enable the rational design of wear resistant polymeric materials featuring graphene building blocks. This project can result in new nano-engineered solid lubricants for improved performance, safety, reliability and affordability in a variety of tribological applications.  


Last Modified: 09/09/2016
Modified by: Nikhil Koratkar

Another important mechanism was shown to be the ability of graphene to affect the crystallinity and microstructure of teflon by stabilizing the tougher phase-I of teflon.
